qas.question: Where is the only iron deposit on earth?
Around what time did bronze start being formed?
What does copper and zinc form to make?
Which metal important to the ancients is the hardest one?
What is usually found his iron ore in Greenland?
What kind of copper is rare on earth?
What was used to make tools in jewelry before Neolithic times?
What did humans began alloying around 2500 A.D.?
What was rare in Great Britain?

context: <b5_0>Iron<b5_0/> is usually found as iron ore on Earth, except for one deposit of native iron in <a0_0>Greenland<a0_0/>, which was used by the Inuit people. <b6_0>Native<b6_0/> copper, however, was found worldwide, along with silver, <b7_0>gold and platinum<b7_0/>, which were also used to make tools, jewelry, and other objects since Neolithic times. <a4_0>Copper<a4_0/> was the hardest of these metals, and the most widely distributed. It became one of the most important metals to the ancients. Eventually, humans learned to smelt metals such as <b8_0>copper and tin<b8_0/> from ore, and, around <a1_0>2500 BC<a1_0/>, began alloying the two metals to form bronze, which is much harder than its ingredients. <b9_0>Tin<b9_0/> was rare, however, being found mostly in <a3_0>Great Britain<a3_0/>. In the Middle East, people began alloying copper with zinc to form <a2_0>brass<a2_0/>. Ancient civilizations took into account the mixture and the various properties it produced, such as hardness, toughness and melting point, under various conditions of temperature and work hardening, developing much of the information contained in modern alloy phase diagrams. Arrowheads from the Chinese Qin dynasty (around 200 BC) were often constructed with a hard bronze-head, but a softer bronze-tang, combining the alloys to prevent both dulling and breaking during use.
